    Researching Wikipedia Holistically: A Tentative Approach

    29 minute read

    Published: October 11, 2008

    This is a tentative article-length introduction to my thesis on Wikipedia. It is an attempt to analyze Wikipedia from an interdisciplinary perspective that tries to make problematic various assumptions, concepts, and relations that function quite well in the âreal worldâ but are not well-suited to studying Wikipedia. I begin by talking about the nature of academic disciplines, then proceed to a detailed but sparse review of certain prior research on Wikipedia. By examining the problems in previous research within the context of disciplines, I establish a tentative methodology for a holistic study of Wikipedia. Read more

    When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: August 16, 2013

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate. Read more

    A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: March 28, 2008

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content. Read more

    A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: March 28, 2008

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content. Read more

    A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: March 28, 2008

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content. Read more

    A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: March 28, 2008

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content. Read more

    Wikimania 2008: Flagged Revisions with Philipp Birken

    5 minute read

    Published: July 20, 2008

    From âFlagged Revisions,â a presentation at Wikimania 2008 by Philip Birken. In my opinion, flagged revisions realize the concept of stable versions without making the article actually stable.Â  It is not a system of voting to approve new revisions â a new revision is approved when only one autoconfirmed user says it is vandalism-free.Â  Yes, it wonât solve everything, but it will make things much better.Â  We can get rid of protecting articles that are experiencing heavy vandalism if we do this, because an edit only updates to the public when it is flagged as not-vandalism by a trusted user. However, vandals (or any other user) immediately sees the results of their edit for an hour, which is just ingenious.Â  Also, you can choose whether the most recent revision is shown by default, or make it so that certain users (like anonymous users) only see the most recent reviewed revision.Â  For those who feel that it threatens âthe wiki way,â I suggest making the most recent version appear by default and giving people the option to see the latest reviewed version.     When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: August 16, 2013

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate. Read more

    When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: August 16, 2013

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate. Read more

    A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: March 28, 2008

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content. Read more

    Wikimania 2008: Flagged Revisions with Philipp Birken

    5 minute read

    Published: July 20, 2008

    From âFlagged Revisions,â a presentation at Wikimania 2008 by Philip Birken. In my opinion, flagged revisions realize the concept of stable versions without making the article actually stable.Â  It is not a system of voting to approve new revisions â a new revision is approved when only one autoconfirmed user says it is vandalism-free.Â  Yes, it wonât solve everything, but it will make things much better.Â  We can get rid of protecting articles that are experiencing heavy vandalism if we do this, because an edit only updates to the public when it is flagged as not-vandalism by a trusted user. However, vandals (or any other user) immediately sees the results of their edit for an hour, which is just ingenious.Â  Also, you can choose whether the most recent revision is shown by default, or make it so that certain users (like anonymous users) only see the most recent reviewed revision.Â  For those who feel that it threatens âthe wiki way,â I suggest making the most recent version appear by default and giving people the option to see the latest reviewed version.     When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: August 16, 2013

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate. Read more

    When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: August 16, 2013

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate. Read more

    Wikimania 2008: Flagged Revisions with Philipp Birken

    5 minute read

    Published: July 20, 2008

    From âFlagged Revisions,â a presentation at Wikimania 2008 by Philip Birken. In my opinion, flagged revisions realize the concept of stable versions without making the article actually stable.Â  It is not a system of voting to approve new revisions â a new revision is approved when only one autoconfirmed user says it is vandalism-free.Â  Yes, it wonât solve everything, but it will make things much better.Â  We can get rid of protecting articles that are experiencing heavy vandalism if we do this, because an edit only updates to the public when it is flagged as not-vandalism by a trusted user. However, vandals (or any other user) immediately sees the results of their edit for an hour, which is just ingenious.Â  Also, you can choose whether the most recent revision is shown by default, or make it so that certain users (like anonymous users) only see the most recent reviewed revision.Â  For those who feel that it threatens âthe wiki way,â I suggest making the most recent version appear by default and giving people the option to see the latest reviewed version.     Wikimania 2008: Flagged Revisions with Philipp Birken

    5 minute read

    Published: July 20, 2008

    From âFlagged Revisions,â a presentation at Wikimania 2008 by Philip Birken. In my opinion, flagged revisions realize the concept of stable versions without making the article actually stable.Â  It is not a system of voting to approve new revisions â a new revision is approved when only one autoconfirmed user says it is vandalism-free.Â  Yes, it wonât solve everything, but it will make things much better.Â  We can get rid of protecting articles that are experiencing heavy vandalism if we do this, because an edit only updates to the public when it is flagged as not-vandalism by a trusted user. However, vandals (or any other user) immediately sees the results of their edit for an hour, which is just ingenious.Â  Also, you can choose whether the most recent revision is shown by default, or make it so that certain users (like anonymous users) only see the most recent reviewed revision.Â  For those who feel that it threatens âthe wiki way,â I suggest making the most recent version appear by default and giving people the option to see the latest reviewed version.     A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: March 28, 2008

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content. Read more

    When the Levee Breaks: Without Bots, What Happens to Wikipediaâs Quality Control Processes?

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: August 16, 2013

    Iâve written a number of papers about the role that automated software agents (or bots) play in Wikipedia, claiming that they are critical to the continued operation of Wikipedia. This paper tests this hypothesis and introduces a metric visualizing the speed at which fully-automated bots, tool-assisted cyborgs, and unassisted humans review edits in Wikipedia. In the first half of 2011, ClueBot NG â one of the most prolific counter-vandalism bots in the English-language Wikipedia â went down for four distinct periods, each period of downtime lasting from days to weeks. Aaron Halfaker and I use these periods of breakdown as naturalistic experiments to study Wikipediaâs quality control network. Our analysis showed that the overall time-to-revert damaging edits was almost doubled when this software agent was down. Yet while a significantly fewer proportion of edits made during the botâs downtime were reverted, we found that those edits were later eventually reverted. This suggests that human agents in Wikipedia took over this quality control work, but performed it at a far slower rate. Read more

    Wikimania 2008: Flagged Revisions with Philipp Birken

    5 minute read

    Published: July 20, 2008

    From âFlagged Revisions,â a presentation at Wikimania 2008 by Philip Birken. In my opinion, flagged revisions realize the concept of stable versions without making the article actually stable.Â  It is not a system of voting to approve new revisions â a new revision is approved when only one autoconfirmed user says it is vandalism-free.Â  Yes, it wonât solve everything, but it will make things much better.Â  We can get rid of protecting articles that are experiencing heavy vandalism if we do this, because an edit only updates to the public when it is flagged as not-vandalism by a trusted user. However, vandals (or any other user) immediately sees the results of their edit for an hour, which is just ingenious.Â  Also, you can choose whether the most recent revision is shown by default, or make it so that certain users (like anonymous users) only see the most recent reviewed revision.Â  For those who feel that it threatens âthe wiki way,â I suggest making the most recent version appear by default and giving people the option to see the latest reviewed version.     A Communicative Ethnography of Argumentative Strategies in a Wikipedian Content Dispute

    less than 1 minute read

    Published: March 28, 2008

    This presentation was adapted from a chapter in my Senior thesis on Wikipediaâs legal system that focused on a dispute over the inclusion of images of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in an article about him, using a methodology of communicative ethnography. Most who opposed the image were not familiar with Wikipediaâs unique method of content regulation and dispute resolution, as well as its editorial standards and principles. However, most who argued in favor of keeping the image knew these and initially used them to their advantage. This ethnographic study of the communicative strategies used by the parties involved in the dispute shows how new editors to the user-written encyclopedia first emerged in a hostile communicative environment and subsequently adapted their argumentative strategies. This conflict is an excellent example of how disputes are resolved in Wikipedia, showing how this new media space regulates its own content. Read more
